newsitem.title: GERMANY: Issing calls for budget hardliner as ECB head.
newsitem.headline: Issing calls for budget hardliner as ECB head.

text.p: The head of Europe's central bank must be a hardline supporter of budgetary control, Bundesbank chief economist Otmar Issing said on Tuesday, steering clear of a debate about possible candidates.

"What is essential is that the president present distinct stability credentials," Issing said, avoiding more specific comment on speculation that Germany and France may be at odds about a candidate for the Frankfurt-based European Central Bank (ECB).

German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung this morning reported that France insists that a Frenchman head the future central bank and has proposed to Germany that Michel Camdessus, head of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) should take the post.
In return, France has promised to support a German candidate to replace Camdessus in Washington.
The report said France continued to oppose Dutch central bank president Wim Duisenberg's candidacy for the top job.
Duisenberg will replace Alexandre Lamfalussy this summer as head of the Frankfurt-based European Monetary Institute, the ECB's forerunner.

Asked about the Bundesbank's position on Duisenberg, Issing said only that Holland and Germany's policies conform in many ways. Duisenberg is considered to have the support of many other European nations as well, the report said.
